issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify Milkable.messageOnMilk() with no parameters (signature: messageOnMilk(): String) and describe its return value as "[Animal Type] [name] is milked". The solution repository defines Milkable.messageOnMilk(double volume) (i.e., it requires a double parameter) and the Seal and Goat implementations also use this volume parameter. This parameter mismatch changes the method contract compared to the specification and will confuse students (and break expected usage such as calls to messageOnMilk() without arguments in the template's Main).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Milkable interface match the problem specification: change the signature to messageOnMilk(): String (no parameters). Update Seal and Goat to implement messageOnMilk() with no parameters and return the string as specified (e.g., "Seal Clarabelle is milked"). Alternatively, if the intent was to include a volume parameter, update the problem statement/UML and any template usage (Main and textual instructions) to document and demonstrate the volume parameter consistently. Preferably align the solution to the current problem/UML (no-arg messageOnMilk) to avoid breaking the described tests and template usage.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and textual requirements) and the template expect a parameterless milk method messageOnMilk() that returns a String like "[Animal Type] [name] is milked". The solution repository, however, defines Milkable.messageOnMilk(double volume) and implements messageOnMilk(double) in Goat and Seal, changing both the method signature and return format (including a volume value). This mismatch between a parameterless method in the problem/template and a method that requires a double in the solution will confuse students (which signature to implement/use), may cause compilation errors when mixing template/example code with the solution, and prevents a clear 1:1 mapping from the requirement to the implemented API.
issues.suggested_fix:
Align the Milkable API across artifacts. Two viable fixes:
1) Preferred (match problem/template): Change the solution to use the parameterless signature String messageOnMilk() in Milkable, and update Goat and Seal to implement messageOnMilk() returning "[Animal Type] [name] is milked". Also ensure any example calls (Main) remain parameterless.
2) Alternatively (match solution): Update the problem statement UML and textual description and the template example calls to require a double volume parameter (messageOnMilk(double volume)) and document the expected return format including the volume. Choose one approach and apply consistently so students have a single, unambiguous API to implement.
